topics.title: AI, org flattening, and managers as ICs
topics.summary: Lenny and Julie discuss orgs flattening, middle managers being cut, and how AI enables individuals to do more work themselves. Julie argues management remains critical, but the nature of resources shifts from people to models/tools.

topics.title: Managing change: the willow tree metaphor
topics.summary: Julie frames modern management as managing accelerating change—being sturdy while flexible. She uses the willow tree metaphor to describe resilience amid uncertainty.

topics.title: Diagnose with data, treat with design
topics.summary: Julie explains her philosophy that data helps identify problems/opportunities, while design creates solutions. She notes many fast-growing companies still underuse data until growth slows and reality forces better instrumentation.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Julie Zhuo, her background at Facebook, her book The Making of a Manager, and her startup Sundial. He previews episode topics and mentions subscriber perks.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Mercury (banking for startups) and DX (developer intelligence platform for AI-era productivity insights).

topics.title: Reunion, podcast growth, and the fireplace Easter egg
topics.summary: Julie and Lenny reflect on the first-ever episode, the shift to video, and Lenny’s recurring fireplace/mirror Easter egg. They also note the podcast’s massive download growth.

topics.title: Re-releasing The Making of a Manager
topics.summary: Julie shares why she wrote the book (to become a better manager) and what surprised her about its broad impact. They position it as a modern counterpart to classic management texts.

topics.title: Everyone becomes a manager of AI agents
topics.summary: They explore how managing people maps to managing agentic systems: setting goals, understanding strengths of different models, and designing processes/tools. Julie emphasizes clear outcomes and context as core leverage.

topics.title: Builders, smaller teams, and no-PM experiments
topics.summary: Julie argues AI dissolves traditional role boundaries, enabling smaller teams of “builders.” She explains why Sundial often avoids hiring PMs to prevent delegation-by-role and push engineers to own product thinking.

topics.title: AI tools accelerating work and learning
topics.summary: Julie describes how AI expands cross-functional capability (engineering, prototyping, analysis) and highlights AI as a personalized teacher. She shares examples of engineers learning analysis context and using AI to test understanding.

topics.title: Why fast-growing AI companies underuse data
topics.summary: Julie explains that hypergrowth often outpaces data infrastructure, so companies run on instincts until growth slows. She also notes new product paradigms (conversational UX) require new analytics methods to infer intent and success.

topics.title: Designers vs data: misconceptions and balance
topics.summary: Julie addresses designer skepticism about data, reiterating data informs reality but doesn’t dictate solutions. She warns against “A/B testing your way” to greatness while advocating thoughtful metric choice and interpretation.

topics.title: AI-era management: uncertainty, fear, and communication
topics.summary: Julie says the biggest shift is the accelerating rate of change and the anxiety it creates about careers and relevance. Managers must communicate clearly, acknowledge fear, and help teams adapt without spiraling into chaos.

topics.title: Timeless advice: manage yourself and dimensionality
topics.summary: Julie emphasizes self-management as foundational for new managers, including understanding strengths/weaknesses without tying them to identity. She introduces “dimensionality” as a way to receive feedback objectively and grow.
